natural problem:
Find the positive value of $x$ which satisfies
\[\log_5 (x - 2) + \log_{\sqrt{5}} (x^3 - 2) + \log_{\frac{1}{5}} (x - 2) = 4.\]
natural solution: By the change-of-base formula, \[\log_{\sqrt{5}} (x^3 - 2) = \frac{\log_5 (x^3 - 2)}{\log_5 \sqrt{5}} = \frac{\log_5 (x^3 - 2)}{1/2} = 2 \log_5 (x^3 - 2),\]and \[\log_{\frac{1}{5}} (x - 2) = \frac{\log_5 (x - 2)}{\log_5 \frac{1}{5}} = -\log_5 (x - 2),\]so the given equation becomes

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x > 2"
and h1 : "log 5 (x - 2) + log (sqrt 5) (x powr 3 - 2) + log (1/5) (x - 2) = 4"
shows  "x = 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the positive value of $x$ which satisfies
\[\log_5 (x - 2) + \log_{\sqrt{5}} (x^3 - 2) + \log_{\frac{1}{5}} (x - 2) = 4.\] The final Answer is 3
 ### Proof
 By the change-of-base formula, \[\log_{\sqrt{5}} (x^3 - 2) = \frac{\log_5 (x^3 - 2)}{\log_5 \sqrt{5}} = \frac{\log_5 (x^3 - 2)}{1/2} = 2 \log_5 (x^3 - 2),\]and \[\log_{\frac{1}{5}} (x - 2) = \frac{\log_5 (x - 2)}{\log_5 \frac{1}{5}} = -\log_5 (x - 2),\]so the given equation becomes
 \[2 \log_5 (x^3 - 2) = 4.\]Then $\log_5 (x^3 - 2) = 2,$ so $x^3 - 2 = 5^2 = 25.$  Then $x^3 = 27,$ so $x = \boxed{3}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real
assumes h0 : "x > 2"
and h1 : "log 5 (x - 2) + log (sqrt 5) (x powr 3 - 2) + log (1/5) (x - 2) = 4"
shows  "x = 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the value of $x$ that satisfies the equation $\log_5(x - 2) + \log_{\sqrt{5}}(x^3 - 2) + \log_{1/5}(x - 2) = 4$, given that $x > 2$. The final answer is $x = 3$.
